snippet: At least 10 states have already met President Obama’s goal of a 30 percent reduction in power plant emissions by 2030, without the economic damage that critics have warned would occur.
abstract: At least 10 states have already cut power plant emissions by level required under new Obama administration proposal, defying critics who claim that plan will lead to soaring electricity bills, blackouts and economic damage; plan may be more difficult to follow in states that are heavily dependent on coal power, while many environmentalists argue that it does not go nearly far enough in addressing climate change.

byline.original: By JUSTIN GILLIS and MICHAEL WINES
byline.contributor: Clifford Krauss, Henry Fountain and Coral Davenport contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: At least 10 states have already met President Obama’s goal of a 30 percent reduction in power plant emissions by 2030, without the economic damage that critics have warned would occur.

headline.main: In Some States, Emissions Cuts Defy Skeptics
headline.print_headline: In Some States, Emissions Cuts Defy Skeptics
